observations: The only file explicitly shown in the blast radius is /app/dclm/ray_processing/tokenize_shuffle.py, but the agent did not edit it.

Both edited files (/app/dclm/ray_processing/process.py and /app/dclm/ray_processing/ray_cluster.yaml) are not indicated as part of the displayed blast radius, suggesting the changes may not be targeting the impacted call graph shown.
impact_alignment.recommendation: The agent should have prioritized reviewing and potentially updating /app/dclm/ray_processing/tokenize_shuffle.py (and any directly connected caller/callee files shown in the visualization) before making changes in process.py or ray_cluster.yaml, or explicitly justified why configuration/entrypoint changes outside the blast radius were necessary despite not appearing in the dependency graph.

observations: The architecture highlights `ray_processing/process.py` as an entry-ish module, so looking there is consistent with understanding the module graph, but it’s not an obvious focal point for a generic `sanitize-git-repo` task unless it contained embedded secrets/paths.

`ray_cluster.yaml` is not represented in the shown module/import architecture (it’s a deployment/config artifact rather than a Python module), so focusing edits there suggests the agent may have operated outside the architectural dependency map rather than following it.

Given the diagram’s presence of `tools/*`, `setup.py`, and training utilities (common places for tokens, endpoints, file paths, and packaging metadata), not inspecting any of those looks like missing several obvious sanitization hotspots.
Only 2 of the 8 edited files are in the provided blast radius (periodic_knot.py and torus.py).

The agent made several edits in core modules (spacecurves/*, invariants.py, representations/*) that are not listed in the blast radius, suggesting either overreach beyond the scoped impact or reliance on knowledge not reflected in the visualization.
Blast-radius items that commonly require updates/verification after behavior changes—tests and make/__init__.py—were not edited, which risks leaving broken imports/behavior unvalidated.
impact_alignment.recommendation: Constrain edits primarily to the files shown in the blast radius, and if changing shared/core behavior outside that set, first confirm those dependencies in the visualization (or regenerate it). At minimum, update or run/adjust the impacted tests (tests/test_knot.py, tests/test_spacecurve.py) and check make/__init__.py for any export/import changes implied by edits to make/periodic_knot.py or make/torus.py.

observations: For a build-cython-ext task, inspecting root setup.py was aligned with the architecture, but the agent did not explore the dedicated pyknotid/spacecurves/setup.py module shown in the diagram, which is the most likely location for Cython extension configuration.

Most edits were made in high-level domain logic modules (spacecurve/knot/openknot, invariants, representations, make/*), which are downstream of the build system; this suggests the agent may have been fixing runtime/logic issues rather than addressing extension build wiring.

The diagram highlights core hub modules (e.g., gausscode.py, utils.py) and spacecurves submodules (helpers.py, periodicline.py) that are plausible Cython targets or dependencies; these were not explored, indicating incomplete coverage of architecture-relevant build components.
The blast radius contains /app/climate_analyzer/analyze_climate.py, but the agent made no edits at all, so there is no evidence of acting on the visualization.
No files were edited outside the blast radius; however, the lack of any edits suggests the agent did not apply the impact analysis to guide changes.
impact_alignment.recommendation: If a change to the analyzed symbol was intended, the agent should have updated /app/climate_analyzer/analyze_climate.py (and then verified any callers/callees shown in the blast radius). If no change was needed, the agent should have explicitly documented that the blast radius was reviewed and no edits were required.

observations: The architecture view shows a single core module (climate_analyzer/analyze_climate.py) with no other in/out dependencies, and the agent did inspect that central file, which aligns with the module structure.

Exploring config.ini is plausibly relevant for runtime behavior, but it is not part of the depicted module dependency graph; exploring the CSV is data inspection rather than architectural/module exploration.

Given the task 'modernize-scientific-stack', some code changes would typically be expected in the main analysis module (e.g., updating pandas/numpy/scipy usage), but the agent made no edits, so their edit pattern does not demonstrate applied understanding.
The only edited file (/app/bottle.py) is explicitly included in the blast radius, so the edit is fully within the impacted set.
No files outside the blast radius were modified, suggesting the agent did not introduce changes in unrelated areas.

Although many dependent test files are in the blast radius, the agent did not modify any of them; this may be fine if the change was non-breaking, but it also may indicate the agent didn’t follow through on validating/updating downstream callers.
impact_alignment.recommendation: After modifying /app/bottle.py, the agent should have checked (and, if needed, updated) the most directly affected tests in the blast radius (e.g., test_app.py, test_wsgi.py, test_router.py, test_route.py) and any related documentation under /app/docs/conf.py if behavior/API changes occurred.

observations: The architecture shows `bottle.py` as a large foundational module with many incoming dependencies; editing it is a plausible and efficient place to fix a cross-cutting vulnerability.

Looking at `test/test_sendfile.py` suggests the agent used the test module that most directly exercises the likely vulnerable behavior (sendfile/path handling), consistent with the dependency-centric layout.
`report.jsonl` is not represented as a module in the architecture diagram and is likely tooling output; viewing it may help triage but doesn’t demonstrate architectural navigation.

Given a sendfile-related vulnerability, adjacent tests like `test/test_fileupload.py` (and possibly `test/test_environment.py` for platform/path edge cases) are obvious secondary places to confirm impact and prevent regressions, but they weren’t explored.
